newsitem.title: GERMANY: Daimler auto sector must remain unified - Feuerstein.
newsitem.headline: Daimler auto sector must remain unified - Feuerstein.

text.p: The chairman of Daimler-Benz AG's works council, Karl Feuerstein, said on Monday that the industrial group's automotive business must remain a single entity in any restructuring of the group.

Feuerstein also said that any supervisory board decision on a restructuring of Daimler would probably not be taken at the next scheduled board meeting on November 6 and would perhaps not be taken until 1997.
In an interview with Reuters, Feuerstein, deputy head of the supervisory board, said Daimler's automotive unit must under no circumstances be split up within the Daimler group.
"We will measure all proposals according to this demand," Feuerstein said.
"We must discuss this comprehensively in the supervisory board," Feuerstein said, adding that the board must not let itself be put under time pressure.
A row has been brewing within Daimler over a proposal by chief executive Juergen Schrempp to integrate Mercedes into Daimler.
Sources close to Daimler have said that six out of seven management board members at Daimler approved the plan. Only Mercedes-Benz chief executive Helmut Werner opposes it, the sources said.

The four-member presidency of the supervisory board, consisting of two employee representatives and two from the shareholders' side, will discuss the plans for a management restructuring at a meeting on Tuesday, Feuerstein said.
Sources close to the company said shareholder representatives on the supervisory board, including the chief executive of Deutsche Bank AG, Hilmar Kopper, would meet on Monday to discuss the changes.
Feuerstein said he did not oppose a new structure in principle but added that the automotive business must not be split up. He did not say how he envisaged this happening as part of a reorganisation.
